messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:18): wonders what idiom "nicely nicely" translates to in dutch :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:21): replies to mail from november 2004
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:21): isn't sure, got it from Ideal (BBC show)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): odd
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): what context do they use it in?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): i've never heard it before
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): google doesn't seem to help
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:22): the main character says it when he's pleased
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): aah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): odd
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): the british, really, you never know what they'll say next
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:23): ooh that reminds me, i have a top gear downloading
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:23): i get to watch it tomorrow evening!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:23): yay
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:23): i was so happy to see top gear on itunes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:24): back on topic, i wonder how to convert <datagrid> to an async API
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:26): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, is that the original or current BBC series, or the US version of Top Gear?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:26): current bbc series
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:27): ok. I've not heard of it. Just reading about it in wikipedia
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:27): you haven't heard of top gear? oh my
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:27): it's awesome
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:27): and i don't even remotely like cars
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:28): apparently there's a new Australian version that started last year
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:28): though it's on SBS, and so even if I were in Australia, I'd be unlikeliy to bother watching it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:29): It seems more like a TV show about people who are making a TV show about cars, rather than actually being a TV show about cars
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:29): the reason to watch it isn't the show concept so much as the execution, and i doubt that other teams would get quite the same result
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:29): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: right
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:32): so is it suitable for people like myself with no interest in cars and/or racing, except for the annual Bathurst 1000?
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:33): very much so
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (12:33): it's suitable for just about anyone :)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:33): alright. I'll download a few episodes later and check it out, if I remember

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:34): (One particular example is that they had a segment filmed in America, and introduced it by saying they only had visas for making documentaries, and the last time they were in America they were accused of having made an entertainment film instead, and there wasn't time to get new visas, so this time they would have to be very careful not to be entertaining)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:34): (which is a bit meta)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:34): yeah, Top Gear is funny, didn't know it was still going on

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:35): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721: according to ken, what i was saying yesterday is indeed google's opinion; he thinks you may have confused his interest in captioning standards for interest in annotation standards

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:35): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721: in particular, we're still very much playing around with annotation so we wouldn't really know what we wanted standardised yet
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:36): I wonder what I confused then
1c32249ea47a56f145a75349f2b0426a (12:36): isn't interested in cars and doesn't watch TV anymore either.. :-p
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:37): anyway - we all know we need to solve the simple case first

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:37): 1c32249ea47a56f145a75349f2b0426a: TV is much more entertaining once you remove all ads, trailers, previews, overlayed images, etc, and make it on-demand and limit it to only quality programming. :-)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, if you're referring to the video annotation "feature" that YouTube has implemented, I really despise that. It has ruined so many otherwise good videos, because people abuse it way too much
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:38): no harm in discussing the future though!
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:39): likes that Top Gear is an hour-long programme and because it's on the BBC it's actually really an hour, not 30 minutes plus adverts :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:39): wonders how <video> rendering in WebKit is threaded
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:40): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: http://www.blogsdna.com/288/turn-off-youtube-video-annotations.htm
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:41): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I always turn them off manually when I see them.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:41): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: i was utterly shocked the first time i was exposed to US TV -- if you think (non-bbc) british tv is bad, you should see tv in the us, holy crap
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:41): I've seriously considered stopping paying for the TV permit and getting rid of the tuner accordingly
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:41): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: they play ads between the teaser and the first act, and between the last act and the credits!
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, unfortunately, there's no way to have them off by default
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:42): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yeah it does seem that way, that's unfortunate
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:42): too bad availability of online movie rentals sucks in Finland
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:42): i don't understand why media companies are still region-limiting availability
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:43): that makes zero sense to me
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:43): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: get a digital tuner card and set up mythtv
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:43): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, I suggest using Giganews and Newzbin for your TV and film needs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:43): why would you ever explicitly _restrict_ your audience?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:43): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721: I have a USB tuner and EyeTV
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:43): then again, they also do drm and stuff, they clearly don't understand the digital age yet
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:43): and you have to pay for that in Finland?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:44): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, it makes some sense for the BBC, since ok UK citizens are paying their BBC TV licences, and other people would just be free loading off them
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:44): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: If you sell something to a wider audience now, you can't sell it to them next year for more money
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:44): s/since ok/since only/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:44): so you lose the opportunity for price discrimination

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:45): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: it makes sense taht the bbc doesn't give away their content internationally, but they don't even sell most of it! top gear is only on iTunes in the US because it is shown on BBC America and BBC America has a separate deal with iTunes!
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:45): I heard this weird argument that audiences outside the target country would need to get different ads and so some sites restrict their region
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:45): it's moronic
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:45): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: why can't yet sell it straight away for more money? by next year, half the audience will have bittorrented it
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:46): we still cannot get Hulu down here
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:46): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: They sell it on DVD, but I don't know if they sell it on US-regioned DVDs so maybe that doesn't help
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:46): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I agree that there should be no restrictions on selling TV shows, films and music worldwide
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:46): it's also moronic that iTunes rentals are available only in a couple of English-language locales
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:46): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I think you overestimate how many people use BitTorrent :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:46): which suggests that someone at Apple thinks that they couldn't offer untranslated content elsewhere
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:47): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i doubt it's apple's fault frankly
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:47): it's usually the content owners (traditional distributors)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): do you mean content owners prohibit untranslated distribution?
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (12:47): they are not entering a new market without knowing how to commercialise it properly

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:47): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: They probably want to negotiate with broadcasters in foreign regions to do the first showing (and thus get millions of viewers and lots of money from advertisers), which takes months or years to sort out and schedule, before distributing it online
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:48): after all, once the content is available in the U.S. and U.K. letting others pay for it would be free money

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:48): unfortunately, the way the rights organisations like the RIAA and MPAA, and their international equivalents are structured, retailers have to negotiate rights in each territory individually, which sucks so much. And they also have to consider release schedules on local TV networks, so they don't compete directly with their old and failing business model
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:49): so is it just a coincidence that the U.K. was the next territory after the U.S.?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:49): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: i would be surprised if they got more money from ads on syndication than they did from iTunes sales to an equal audience. And if it's not an equal audience, then one still doesn't preclude the other.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: sometimes the UK is first, even (e.g. some babylon 5 and sg-1 episodes aired in the UK before the US)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:50): basically the entire media industry is aniquated
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:50): anyway
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:50): anyway, when Steve promised "Internation later this year [2008]", I expected something more than just the U.K.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, Australia got some TV series too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:51): i expect he did too

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:51): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: You can't really broadcast a nationwide exclusive of some series if 5% of people have already downloaded it on iTunes and know exactly what's going to happen and give spoilers to everyone else and ruin the excitement
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:52): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yes because national boundaries are really effective at stopping _that_ problem

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:53): I stopped watching series, because the broadcast distribution model just sucks for them--you have to capture the data at a certain time, and the time isn't stable because sports are allowed to go overtime
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:54): i recommend interning with some US company, getting a US credit card, and keeping it when you leave

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:54): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, the fact is that refusing to sell content directly to consumers only ignores the fact that Usenet and BitTorrent are already catering to that market well
1c32249ea47a56f145a75349f2b0426a (12:55): even my sister uses torrent. :)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:55): I only use torrent when something isn't available on Usenet because torrents can be and are actively tracked by rights organisations, whereas usenet can't be
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:57): my neighbours try to use torrent
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:58): i block it because they aren't any good at bandwidth management and it takes down my network
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:58): (personally i just use HTTP to download tv shows)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:59): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Rights organisations could get the news servers taken down for hosting illegal content, and then replace them with servers run by themselves which log all accesses
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:00): but they don't :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:00): (yet, anyway)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:01): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, if they were running the servers, then they're the ones providing access and they can't turn around and accuse users of obtaining illegal access

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:01): I guess the main difference is that people get caught/punished for uploading content (which will happen in any P2P system), not for downloading it (which is all that happens in Usenet)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:01): but Usenet servers are protected by the DMCA safe harbour provisions in the US, and similar laws in other countries
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:03): so what you're saying is p2p systems should be written in such a way as to be covered by safe-harbour provisions...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, yes, if that's possible
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:03): that i want to see
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:03): for the comedic value if nothing else
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:03): like a Freenet-like P2P system
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:03): I don't think I'd want to rely on a "safe harbour" defence when the service's entire reason for existence is to serve illegal content to people
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:03): unfortunately, Freenet is a little too slow for such things
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:03): bittorrent is used for far more than illegal content
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:14): Grokster served legal content too, but its main usage and reason for existence was to serve illegal content
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:14): which seems to be about the same situation as Usenet binaries
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Usenet binaries can be used for distributing copies of perl
